verses.text: Now these are the people of the province who came up out of the captivity, whom Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon had carried away to Babylon. They returned to Jerusalem and Judah, each to his own town.
verses.comment: This verse begins the listing of the exiles who returned from Babylon, highlighting the faithfulness of God in preserving His people and returning them to their inheritance.

verses.text: They came with Zerubbabel, Jeshua, Nehemiah, Seraiah, Reelaiah, Mordecai, Bilshan, Mispar, Bigvai, Rehum, and Baanah. The number of the men of the people of Israel:
verses.comment: Leadership is emphasized by naming the heads leading the return. Zerubbabel (Davidic line) and Jeshua (priesthood) foreshadow Christ as both King and High Priest (Heb. 4:14; Rev. 17:14).

verses.text: The sons of Parosh, two thousand one hundred seventy-two.
verses.comment: Names and numbers highlight the restoration of families and tribes, echoing God's covenant faithfulness.

verses.text: The sons of Shephatiah, three hundred seventy-two.
The sons of Arah, seven hundred seventy-five.
The sons of Pahath-moab, namely the sons of Jeshua and Joab, two thousand eight hundred twelve.
verses.comment: Jeshua signifies the continuation of priestly families, vital in the worship life of Israel, prefiguring Christ the ultimate Priest (Heb. 7:23-27).

verses.text: The sons of Elam, one thousand two hundred fifty-four.
The sons of Zattu, nine hundred forty-five.
The sons of Zaccai, seven hundred sixty.
The sons of Bani, six hundred forty-two.
The sons of Bebai, six hundred twenty-three.
The sons of Azgad, one thousand two hundred twenty-two.
The sons of Adonikam, six hundred sixty-six.
verses.comment: The number 666 here is simply a tally of people; it carries no symbolic meaning in context, distinct from its usage in Revelation.

verses.text: The sons of Bigvai, two thousand fifty-six.
The sons of Adin, four hundred fifty-four.
The sons of Ater, namely of Hezekiah, ninety-eight.
verses.comment: Hezekiah’s descendants show the preservation of Davidic lineage, critical for the messianic hope (Isa. 11:1).

verses.text: The sons of Bezai, three hundred twenty-three.
The sons of Jorah, one hundred twelve.
The sons of Hashum, two hundred twenty-three.
The sons of Gibbar, ninety-five.
The sons of Bethlehem, one hundred twenty-three.
verses.comment: Bethlehem is highlighted in messianic prophecy as the birthplace of Christ (Micah 5:2; Matt. 2:1).

verses.text: The men of Netophah, fifty-six.
The men of Anathoth, one hundred twenty-eight.
The sons of Azmaveth, forty-two.
The sons of Kiriath-arim, Chephirah, and Beeroth, seven hundred forty-three.
The sons of Ramah and Geba, six hundred twenty-one.
The men of Michmas, one hundred twenty-two.
The men of Bethel and Ai, two hundred twenty-three.
The sons of Nebo, fifty-two.
The sons of Magbish, one hundred fifty-six.
verses.comment: Not all names have New Testament significance, but their preservation reflects God’s care for every community.

verses.text: The sons of the other Elam, one thousand two hundred fifty-four.
The sons of Harim, three hundred twenty.
The sons of Lod, Hadid, and Ono, seven hundred twenty-five.
The sons of Jericho, three hundred forty-five.
verses.comment: Jericho was connected to the conquest under Joshua (Josh. 6). Returning here symbolizes God's continuing promises.

verses.text: The sons of Senaah, three thousand six hundred thirty.
The priests: the sons of Jedaiah, of the house of Jeshua, nine hundred seventy-three.
verses.comment: Priests play a key role in offering sacrifice and mediating between God and His people, hinting at their foreshadowing of the eternal mediation of Christ (Heb. 5:5-10).

verses.text: The sons of Immer, one thousand fifty-two.
The sons of Pashhur, one thousand two hundred forty-seven.
The sons of Harim, one thousand seventeen.
The Levites: the sons of Jeshua and Kadmiel, of the sons of Hodaviah, seventy-four.
verses.comment: Levites, distinct from priests but essential to temple ministry, anticipate the service role fulfilled ultimately in Christ’s one sacrifice (Heb. 9:12-14).

verses.text: The singers: the sons of Asaph, one hundred twenty-eight.
verses.comment: The sons of Asaph are linked to temple worship and Psalms, showing the importance of sacred music in the worship life of God’s people.

verses.text: The sons of the gatekeepers: the sons of Shallum, Ater, Talmon, Akkub, Hatita, and Shobai, one hundred thirty-nine.
verses.comment: Gatekeepers protected the sanctity of worship, foreshadowing the guardianship of God’s house (see Acts 20:28 for similar spiritual oversight in the early church).

verses.text: The temple servants: the sons of Ziha, Hasupha, and Tabbaoth;
verses.comment: Temple servants (Nethinim) performed necessary services—a reminder that all roles in God’s house are honored (cf. 1 Cor. 12:27-31).

verses.text: The sons of Keros, Siaha, and Padon;
The sons of Lebanah, Hagabah, and Akkub;
The sons of Hagab, Shalmai, and Hanan;
The sons of Giddel, Gahar, and Reaiah;
The sons of Rezin, Nekoda, and Gazzam;
The sons of Uzza, Paseah, and Besai;
The sons of Asnah, Meunim, and Nephusim;
The sons of Bakbuk, Hakupha, and Harhur;
The sons of Bazluth, Mehida, and Harsha;
The sons of Barkos, Sisera, and Temah;
The sons of Neziah and Hatipha.
The sons of Solomon’s servants: the sons of Sotai, Hassophereth, Peruda,
verses.comment: Solomon’s servants reflect continuity with Israel’s kingly tradition.

verses.text: The sons of Jaalah, Darkon, and Giddel,
The sons of Shephatiah, Hattil, Pochereth-hazzebaim, and Ami.
All the temple servants and the sons of Solomon’s servants were three hundred ninety-two.
The following came up from Tel-melah, Tel-harsha, Kerub, Addan, and Immer, but they could not prove their father’s house or their descent, whether they were of Israel:
verses.comment: Genealogy and valid descent are necessary for service in Israel’s worship, foreshadowing the value Christ places on spiritual adoption (Rom. 8:14-17).

verses.text: The sons of Delaiah, the sons of Tobiah, and the sons of Nekoda, six hundred fifty-two.
Also, of the sons of the priests: the sons of Habaiah, the sons of Hakkoz, and the sons of Barzillai (who took a wife from the daughters of Barzillai the Gileadite and was called by their name).
verses.comment: Priests outside clear ancestry were excluded, demonstrating the importance of tradition and apostolic succession for teaching authority.

verses.text: These searched for their family records but could not find them, so they were disqualified from the priesthood as unclean.
verses.comment: Spiritual authority is not self-designated but depends on recognized lineage, a principle underscored in apostolic ministry (1 Tim. 4:14).

verses.text: The governor told them that they should not eat of the most holy food until a priest could consult the Urim and Thummim.
verses.comment: The necessity to confirm the priesthood by divine means foreshadows the reliance on spiritual authority and tradition for sacramental matters.

verses.text: The whole assembly together was forty-two thousand three hundred sixty,
verses.comment: A unified number demonstrates God’s call of all His people into one body (cf. John 17:21; Eph. 4:4).

verses.text: besides their male and female servants, of whom there were seven thousand three hundred thirty-seven. There were also two hundred male and female singers.
verses.comment: Worship, service, and inclusion of various roles evidence a structured community centered in liturgy and prayer.

verses.text: Their horses were seven hundred thirty-six, their mules two hundred forty-five,
their camels four hundred thirty-five, and their donkeys six thousand seven hundred twenty.
Some of the heads of families, when they came to the house of the LORD that is in Jerusalem, made offerings willingly for the house of God, to set it up in its place.
verses.comment: Voluntary offerings for the temple underscore the call to generosity for the worship of God—a form of spiritual sacrifice (Rom. 12:1).

verses.text: According to their ability they gave to the treasury for the work sixty-one thousand drachmas of gold, five thousand minas of silver, and one hundred priestly garments.
So the priests, the Levites, some of the people, the singers, the gatekeepers, and the temple servants lived in their towns, and all the rest of Israel in their towns.
verses.comment: The restoration of sacred order—priests, Levites, and laity—prefigures the structured worship and order of God’s people, reflecting the importance of unity, traditions, and the visible community of believers (cf. Acts 2:42-47).
